Decisions We Made¶

  • Django over Flask: Django is a much more full and practical choice for our website.
  • Heroku over Google App Engine: Heroku’s database is PostGreSQL, relatively simple to use with Django. Google App Engine uses NoSQL, much more difficult to use.
  • Extend built in User model with UserProfile model so that we can add more information to use later, such as a profile picture.
  • Allow for multiple ciphers to be applied in a single challenge.
  • Check if a proposed solution is correct on the server, less vulnerable to hacking.
  • The difficulty of a challenge is the difficulty of its hardest cipher since in many cases the application of lesser ciphers do not increase the difficulty and if they do, they don’t increase it by much.
  • Push notifications over email: Use push notifications to alert users to invitations to join a challenge instead of emails.
  • Use Whitenoise with Heroku to serve static files.
  • We chose not to switch to the Django Rest framework since it would require a lot of refactoring and we didn’t have the time.
  • We chose a paper background and a title font that look pre-20th century since that’s when hand ciphers were in use.
  • We chose to display other user’s usernames on the challenge page and in the forums to provide anonynimity.
  • We left the test files out of the pylint score since many of the lines look unused to pylint but they are necessary for unit test functionality, such as all lines and functions involving mock.
